collection.title: Lost control
collection.description: spent a lot of time with iskra's work and it always hits me with a deep sense of ephemerality. her systems feel soft and delicate. like a passing leaf that is here and then gone, unnoticed by the normal eye and lost in the monotony of life. she captures these fleeting moments, helping viewers understand an aesthetic essence to the simpler things.

collection.title: CSRSNT-ZAAI-45-of-64.png
collection.description: always been enamored by casey's work. the depth and intricacies of his pieces from seemingly simple diagonal lines and dashes. takes a special eye to be able to imagine, create and express these aesthetics, casey's eye has always been a favorite of mine.

collection.title: The Starry Night: Not Van Gogh, Not Sorry
collection.description: gans have always been my favorite sub-genre of AI, machine-learning, generative, or 'whatever u want to call it' art. fondness for simpler, more personalized systems. early gan outputs allowed more room for contemplation, emotions, and freedom for the machines to dream. there's a rawness to gans, an aesthetic that feels refreshing and incomparable to other artistic explorations. helena's work with gans is the perfect representation of this.... her style, emotions, story and so much more is expressed through her systems, digitally and physically.

collection.title: Lushtemples — landscape in dark tones
collection.description: say what you want about how skeuomorphic or not digital art should or shouldnt be. zancan crafted something special with his early tezos forestry. an artist that captured an entire chain and is a big reason for helping pushing our niche art nerd scene forward just a little more.

collection.title: Window Still Life 064
collection.description: my partner first recognized john's work from early tumblr days, we became active collectors of his daily windows throughout the early hicetnunc days. fond memories of auto-refreshing tzkt pages, waiting for a mint operations to come through… this one has always been a personal favorite, reminds me of my brother and the countless hours we'd share in front of split-screen tvs.

collection.title: Infinite Garden: 12879 Flowers
collection.description: leander's infinite garden series is a beautiful example of protocol art. becoming the gardener of the digital floral arrangement through online contracts. leander doesn't shy away from hard edges, there's no rush towards realism, but rather a meditative retreat in a field of polygons. cool guy makes cool artwork.

collection.title: Genomes #369
collection.description: one of the most under-appreciated projects in the space. such a lovely blend of aesthetics between two legends, mordvinstev and ciphrds ability to create a procedural system that is reminiscent of the early deepdream textures is *chefs kiss*. can sit and watch this living genome evolve forever.

collection.title: Apparitions #842
collection.description: just a special piece from early days of collecting, surrounded with seemingly nostalgic and fond memories. my partner and i have always said our colors are green and pink, this piece reminds me of her. <3

collection.title: fl(uu)f. luluxxx
collection.description: lulu is an og in the cryptoart space. part of the larger p(jj)tch series, these cat gifs are always a dopamine injection. whatever ascii filter/style transfer system lulu has built is a work of art in itself, a signature style thats unforgettable. also who doesnt love cats?

collection.title: Standard Deck 022
collection.description: elna's illusionary flashing style is such a neat way of conveying motion. all the cards within the standard deck series have a life, a scene, a feeling. i like to imagine the band is playing tezeta by mulatu astatke

collection.title: an inefable momento rainbow
collection.description: marcelo's work is a breath of fresh air. a child-like whimsy in this piece. the piece was dedicated to the special group of bird n worm lovers, iykyk. one of the few groups in this space who've never seem to stray from true n honest intentions.

collection.title: 08_26_23_Pixel_Rug_01_THANK_YOU
collection.description: the greatest digital rug weaver there is. travess is the best blend of aesthetic intuition and obsessive curiosity, someone who builds systems from obsessions. a walking encycolpedia of the coolest art references u can ever know.

collection.title: breathing
collection.description: erin's work feels almost prodigious with how early she was to exploring complex gan systems for her age. this piece has always been a favorite, a meditative drift… it was gifted to my partner and i from evan aka metaissance, one of the most honest collectors in this space who has a real love for the works and artists he collects from. have been lucky enough to meet him n his lovely family through this odd interconnected on-chain community.

collection.title: Impossible Architecture #1
collection.description: a piece that scratches my civil engineering brain. love trying to imagine what these procedurally generated floorplans might look like. anders hoff has always been a champion in clean systems.

writings.title: changing tools
writings.description: The evolution of the syntax labor to intent engineering.
body: we're hitting a strange crossroads as accessible tools evolve. it's the difference between a carpenter who spends all day perfecting a single dovetail joint by hand versus someone using a CNC machine to have 100x the production rate. the end product might look identical, but the mental task model of the person making it is completely different.

for the traditional developer, the manual dexterity of syntax and debugging is where the physical craft lives. but as tools evolve, that skill set starts to feel like a constraint. we're shifting toward intent engineering, where the value isn't in how well you can type, but how clearly you can envision the integration of complex systems. it's a shift from being the worker on the floor to being the one who understands the entire production pipeline.
i see people asking...

body.text: if anyone can make software, why do we need developers?

body: ...well, anyone CAN make a sandwich, but we still have thousands of sandwich shops. vibe coders are throwing together a midnight grilled cheese with half-stale bread—it gets the job done (maybe). it still takes an educated figure to understand how to scale this process or refine it.

writings.title: software becoming softer
writings.description: malleability of systems ensures for more fluid workflows
body: in traditional computer science, "spaghetti code" is an ultimate sin because a human eventually has to go back in and fix it or build on top if it. but if an ai can refactor or entirely rewrite ten thousand lines of messy code in a few seconds, does the "cleanliness" even matter anymore? does claude even need to refactor code, or can it just live and work through an entangled mess of sloppy code?

traditional software systems are built to last, but they're rigid. once the concrete sets, you're locked in emotionally and financially. programmers who've spent years building softwares, databases and connected workflows through specific stacks are constrained to their foundational creations. transitioning is a possibility but realistically ill-advised in most scenarios.

this is where the disposability of code takes on a new role. in the physical world, throwing things away is a tragedy of waste. but in code, "permanence" is often just a fancy word for legacy debt…a time sink fallacy that creates bias in intentions and ambitions.

"vibe coding" (or whatever we want to call this ephemeral style) helps move away from the rigid structures. new frameworks, new uis, new themes, new ideas, new everything can be tried, tested and implemented without the risk of having to start from ground up again.

it raises a real question: is it better to spend six months building a "robust" monument thats meant to stand the test of time, or one weekend building a tool that you're totally fine with deleting on monday?

is this a wasteful thought process? an efficient one? how does disposability and waste in the digital world effect us. "soft"ware is meant to be soft…its meant to be malleable, does ai coding make software even softer?

writings.title: machine literacy
writings.description: the gap between owning a device and understanding its potential
body: it is a wild realization that we've taken literal rocks and transformed them into computational super-machines capable of global communication. it becomes an even wilder realization when you consider how early we are in this digital timeline of human history. every year, these devices become more advanced and more intertwined with our existence, yet most of us are locked out of their true potential.

we're limited to experiencing a machine's power through the narrow lens of corporate software, private applications and patented hardwares. you can't tap into a computer's raw mathematical strength without a specific calculator app, and you can't touch its rendering capabilities without a pre-built video game. your phone is packed with lidar, accelerometers and neural engines, but they're basically paperweights unless you're using an app that actually USES these capabilities. it's like owning a high-end laboratory but only being allowed to use the magnifying glass because you dont know how to work with anything else.

but if ai-assisted coding allows the average person to build their own interaction layers to these built in capabilities, the gate collapses. the machine's full capability moves from being a restricted service to a personal utility, making the true power of the "rock" accessible to anyone with an intent and ability to convey it.

it isn't just about "knowing how to code", it's about having the conceptual map to know what is EVEN possible. if you don't realize your phone has a lidar sensor that can map a room in 3d, you'll never think to ask an ai to help you build a tool that measures your furniture. if you don't understand that your gpu is a parallel-processing monster, you'll continue to let it sit idle while you struggle with manual data entry.
the machine stops being a collection of icons and starts being a raw utility. it's about reclaiming the agency to use the laboratory, not just the magnifying glass

writings.title: vibe coder to vibe learner
writings.description: building a personal learning framework with claude
body: As a newly titled "vibe coder" the one thing I've really enjoyed when using Claude is the ambition to learn it instills in me. This ambition has only inspired me to explore ideas I've never thought id be capable of before.

Prior to Claude I wasn't completely unaware of how programming, systems or even computers worked in general but I was still so lost on how most computing structures were built. Being chronically online since a little kid, there's been a handful of occasions where I've wanted to get more technical with my use of computers. At 12 years old I created my own Runescape private server on an old website that hosted RSPS webclients. The site allowed you to choose a specific client base for the game and allowed you to host and edit a server for others to play on. The site only allowed you to control server-sided files and not the client side so you could change the text dialogue of a character, stats of a weapon, or experience rates BUT you couldn't do many of the fun (and arguably more technical) client side programming. This meant no cool custom monsters, custom weapon models or changing combat animations. Although quite a "boiler templated" process, it was still a large learning journey in setting up a running server people could connect to, using compiling systems to push updates, and even managing a small online community. Funny enough, the naivety of my 12 year old self became a bit too ambitious with trying to learn programming and began creating my own custom client to excitingly begin exploring custom 3D asset creation....but long story short, I'd eventually download a virus, get RAT-ed, become terrified of malware and slowed down on my online digging and downloading for a short while after.

Fast forward years and I'd still continuously explore more small programming endeavors in similar ways, curiously trying to mess with digital tools, programming languages, on-chain contracts, etc. I'd always get spurts of energy to try and learn more but would have a hard time even knowing what I should be learning. Should I dive into JS, HTML, CSS, C+.... should I learn frontend or backend practices...there was so many interesting aspects of computer science that intersected my hobbies that it was hard to find what to focus on.

Claude has only made me want to understand programming more. The languages, how computers interpolate data, best practices, the whole shebang (pun intended). The idea that Claude could potentially help guide me to gaining a better broad understanding of computers so I could be better informed on what exactly I wanted to drill into, explore and learn.
This led me to asking Claude to act as more of a professor by building out an educational framework that'd work with my current abilities and knowledge.

The best part of Claude (or ML/AI in general) is the adaptability it provides. Rather than creating a rigid learning course tool that already exists for free all over the web, I could create a learning system that Claude updated, refined and adapted to how I was learning, working and processing information. Imagine doing leetcode or any online-lesson that you feel like could use a bit better explaining, more visual examples, or just additional information that'd help you better understand the topic at hand. Well with Claude working in parallel, it allowed for just that, I could give feedback as the lesson plans went on to improve the overall framework of the course. Finish up a Claude generated lesson that didn't seem to explain a topic or term well enough about? Prompt Claude to dive deeper.

body.text: Well some online courses already provide AI assistants to better explain ideas, so what's different?

body: The difference here, is that the learning framework, user interface, and imbedded features ARE ALL ADAPTABLE. You aren't stuck in the corporatized framework built by some arbitrary design team. You get to be the master of the creation and utility. Maybe you want a "flash-card" feature that gives you easily reviewable flashcards for important terms that can quickly be studied for definitions or use case examples. Simply explaining that feature structure to Claude can probably get you something close to it! Previous SaaS tools can be redefined to Software as a Seed. Open-source programs that act as bases for others to have Claude or any LLM model build from.

Another big benefit to this was expanding on the idea that everyone learns differently, whether that's visually, auditory, hands on examples, flash cards, pop quizzes, or structured note taking. Personal learning processes are SO unique. This is a concept public schooling is always attempting to tackle... "What are the best ways to creating learning plans that benefit most types of learners?" This project was made to let me cater to MY preferred learning methods each step of the way.

Since Claude also has root access, it can directly read my projects, files, conversations and insights to better cater lessons for me. There's no amount of questions, preference sliders, or profile tag selections a private company could track that would generate a better customized lesson plan than Claude can with it having access to your entire filebase, context and quarks. Claude can understand your exact stack preferences, coding patterns, project MVPs to better guide you to improving your knowledge base.

This can become a symbiotic relationship. As the saying goes..."A fool doesn't know what he doesn't know." As Claude helps you improve my understandings, I'll only learn more unknowns, leading to future lessons plans! Reverse the Dunning-Kruger effect. There is a grace in being naive today, so long as you possess the ambition to outgrow it by tomorrow.

What can go wrong? Well maybe a lot. LLMs in general love to hallucinate, and even occasionally, take shortcuts to skip things. If Claude begins give lessons built around false information, the idea is kind of ruined BUT I'm hopeful most information it'll give will still better my understanding in totality.
My long goal? To continue being ambitious about learning new things, systems and ideas.

website.description: my personal corner of the web
details: been chronically online my entire life. garnered an affinity for cool personal websites ever since early runescape forum days. never had the ability to really craft what ive imagined….theres a lyric from a band i loved…. "youre an artist and your mind wont work the way you want it to." i could never get the computer to work the way i wanted bc we communicated in different languages.

contemporary tools have allowed me to voice the vision ive always had to create my own personal hub in the infinite universe we call the internet. my runescape house, my club penguin igloo, my website.

a collection gallery for art and thoughts around it, a writings section for ramblings, projects to see what im tinkering with, and are.na pulls for what inspires me the most. who knows what ill wanna add next
a project born from the dread of maintaining healthy eating habits. i wanted a simple tool that could take a list of available ingredients in house and recommend dishes i could instantly make.

this expanded into working with recipes i was partially missing ingredients for, to help build shopping lists quick without having to rack your brain on what's missing only to get back from the grocery store realizing you needed three other things.

eventually built in a meal planning section that allows you to catalogue meals you want to eat for the week, generates a shopping list of ingredients you need to fulfill those weekly meals. added specific diet restriction filters to help maintain allergy, calorie or other nutritional needs.
draw layouts and components in a sketch interface, then export to clean html/css. a tool for rapid prototyping without leaving the browser.

latent-sync.title: Better Persistent Memory System
latent-sync.description: transforming claude from a temporary contractor into a long-term partner
details: traditional coding sessions are ephemeral; once the context window fills up or the chat resets, the "intellectual momentum" is lost. latent sync transforms claude from a temporary contractor into a long-term partner by creating a feedback loop between active development (NOW.md) and core project rules (CLAUDE.md).
the machine's "memory" is a living asset you curate, better manage your Claude.md file.

arena-graph.description: a visual explorer for your are.na channels
details: i spend a lot of time on are.na saving things that catch my eye but never had a good way to see how everything connects. this pulls all your channels and blocks from the api and renders them as an interactive graph using cytoscape.js. channels become hubs, blocks become nodes, and you can finally see the web of references you've been building.

the fetch script auto tags everything at build time, pulling artist names, mediums, themes and source domains from block metadata. no ml, just pattern matching. from there you get search, a gallery view, path finding between any two blocks, constellation mode that draws connections between blocks sharing tags, category and channel filters, age heatmaps, and a stats panel. one html file, no build step.

claude-obsidian-assistant.description: a starter obsidian vault wired for claude code
details: wanted a structured place where claude could actually manage my notes alongside me. fork the repo, open it as a vault, and claude gets context on the whole system through a root CLAUDE.md file. comes with a johnny decimal folder structure, a /obsidian skill that syncs project info from any working directory, and architecture canvas generation that maps out your codebase visually.

the main thing is the /obsidian skill. run it from any project and claude reads your codebase, matches it to a vault file, and gives you options to update project docs, write dev logs, or generate full architecture diagrams as native obsidian canvas files. it's a template meant to be adjusted, just a starting point to get claude oriented faster.

cyberclaude.title: cyberClaude
cyberclaude.description: personal dashboard monitor specialized for claude
details: cyberclaude is basically a cyberpunk skin for the claude cli, built so it feels like a native desktop app rather than just another terminal window. it's designed to turn the standard command-line experience into something more immersive and functional.

the project handles everything from session management, usage tracking, custom agent manager, better skill/plugin explorer. it's moving the cli away from being a "boring" text prompt and making it a more centralized command center for your projects.

the dashboard acts as a central hub where you can browse old sessions to quickly resume your most recent project. tab-based terminal for running multiple claude instances at once in an organized fashion, and a dedicated agents view where you can see all your custom tools and launch them with a single click, drag them into sessions, and edit. built in a usage tracker that estimates token consumption and gives you a visual timeline of your activity.
